p: Several studies have shown rosemary properties to achieve good sensory results and the reduction of lipid oxidation after addition into foods: Stoick et al. [ 59] used 500–1000 ppm of rosemary extracts in beef; Shahidi et al. [ 60] used rosemary at 200 and 1000 ppm in different foods; Huisman et al. [ 61] used a concentration of 0.05% in pork; Sánchez-Escalante et al. [ 62] used a combination of 500 ppm vitamin C and 1000 ppm of rosemary in beef burgers; Formanek et al. [ 63] used 0.25% of rosemary in beef burgers. In general, all these authors showed that rosemary inhibited the formation of hydroperoxides [ 64].
